data.title: Great Songs Of The ’80s – Greatest Hits 98.1
data.text:
This week’s featured Great Song of the ’80s is literally a salute to 60s rock.

And by literally, I mean it’s the actual subtitle of “R.O.C.K. in the U.S.A!”

The track was a last minute addition to John’ Cougar Mellencamp’s “Scarecrow” album…and that’s because initially, he didn’t want to include a party song on an album that was full of dark and moody material about corporate greed and the decay of the societal foundations of rural America.

But his manager talked him into it. 🙂

Like many of us of a certain age, John listened to AM Top 40 radio stations growing up, and was influenced by the mix of genres played on the air, every hour of every day!

“R.O.C.K. in the U.S.A.” not only paid tribute to those songs, but to the artists who sang them…and the dreams of Rock & Roll stardom they instilled in the youth of the ’60s—like John.

And in addition to including instrumental nods to some of the best musical styles of the ’60s, he dropped the names of several stars of the decade.

As you might imagine, the song was big hit, reaching #2 on Billboard’s Hot 100, and #7 on Canada’s Top 40.

“R.O.C.K. in the U.S.A. (A Salute to ’60s Rock)” by John Cougar Mellencamp: ‘A Great Song of the ’80s…about the ’60s!

John “Mutt” Lange is a South African Producer/songwriter who some of you might know as Shania Twain’s ex-husband.

That factoid is just for reference purposes, because this week’s Great Song of 1982 has to do with Mutt’s history with a group called Clover, and how complete failure resulted in a name change, and a new direction.

Clover had moved from San Francisco to London in an effort to make their mark on rock music. Mutt produced two albums for them, and unfortunately, they both tanked.

So Clover moved back to California, changed their name to Huey Lewis and the News, and scored a “Last Chance” record deal with Chrysalis Records.

Their first album for the label tanked as well, and Chrysalis gave them fair warning: They’d support another album, but it if didn’t contain a hit single, they were done.

It was strongly suggested that they cover a song that originally had been recorded by a British group called Supercharge: “We Both Believe in Love.”

Huey and the boys did NOT like the idea. The problem? The song was written by Mutt Lange.

The general opinion was that if they had failed twice with Mutt, why should they take another chance?

But…under the circumstances, they realized a compromise would be in their best interest…but only if Huey could change the title to “Do You Believe in Love,” and alter the lyrics accordingly.

Permission was granted, and the song was added to their 1982 album “Picture This.”

When it was released as a single, lo and behold, it became their first hit, climbing to #7 on Billboard’s Hot 100! (Oddly, it was an even bigger hit in Iceland, where it reached #2!)

Another factor in the song’s success was the fact that in the infancy of MTV, very few American groups were producing videos, whereas it had been standard procedure in European countries for several years. They were knee-deep in import videos, so they were more than happy to receive “Do You Believe in Love,” and played it in heavy rotation.

The whole thing was a learning experience for the “News,” and from that point on, they worked hard to make sure every album included a hit or two. And the hits just kept on coming!

But it all started when they took a third chance with Mutt Lange.

Do You Believe in Love” by Huey Lewis and the News: a late start on the road to success, but the first of their MANY Great Songs of the ’80s!

Supercharge version:

This Weeks’s Featured Great Song of the ’80s was also was a Great Song of the ’90s!

So how does something like that that happen? I

Well, in the case of “I’m Gonna Be (500 Miles)” by Charlie & Craig Reid, the Scottish duo known as The Proclaimers, it all boiled down to geography.

In 1988, they wrote the song while waiting to travel to a gig, and it was later added to their second album, “Sunshine on Leith.”

It was then released as a single, and promptly climbed to #1 in The UK, Australia, New Zealand and Iceland.

One critic called it “highly rhythmic pop,” while another called it a rousing romantic ditty.” It was both of those things…but unfortunately, it wasn’t released in North America.

At least, not yet.

But then in 1993, “I’m Gonna Be” was featured in the film “Benny & Joon,” starring Johnny Depp and Mary Stuart Masterson, and it was released as a single from the soundtrack album in both the US and Canada.

And just like that, it was a hit “all over again for the first time,” reaching #4 up North, and #3 here in the States.

And that’s how “I’m Gonna Be Be (500 Miles) became a a Great Song of the 80’s AND the ’90s!

With the Olympics still in full swing, it’s the perfect time to highlight 1988’s “One Moment in Time” by Whitney Houston!

The song was written by Albert Hammond (the man behind “It Never Rains in Southern California”) and John Bettis for the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, and released as a single from the Olympic soundtrack compilation album of the same name–produced in conjunction with NBC Sports.

The single was the studio version of the song that Whitney sang live during the opening ceremonies.

(Note: Other artists featured on the album included The Four Tops, The Bee Gees, Eric Carmen, Taylor Dayne and composer/conductor John Williams.)

“One Moment in Time” was an anthem for believing in yourself against all odds, and struck a chord not only in America, but around the world.

The proof: It charted in 20 countries, all but 3 in the top 10! In the US alone, it topped Billboard’s Adult Contemporary Chart, and reached #5 on the Hot 100!

“One Moment in Time” by Whitney Houston gets the Gold Medal for being: an inspirational Song of Olympic proportions…and a Great Song of 1988!

Guitarist Paul Dean of the Canadian group Loverboy went to a nearby beach on a sunny Wednesday afternoon…hoping to find something that might inspire him to write a song.

What he found was a distinct lack of people. In fact, the beach was nearly deserted.

It occurred to him that everybody must be “waiting for the weekend.”

Then it occurred to him that “Waiting for the Weekend” was a great song title. But not so fast…

When he took it back to the group, vocalist Mike Reno thought a better title would be “Working for the Weekend.” And so…a Great Song of 1982 was born!

At the time, Loverboy had only released one album, and they were struggling, playing to small crowds in small bars across Canada and the US…but once they added the finished song to their playlist, they started packing the dance floors. and they knew they were onto something.

In late 1981,”Working for the Weekend” became the lead single from their second album, “Get Lucky,” and–as luck would have it–by early ‘1982, they’d hit the jackpot!

In Canada, the song reached #10 on the Top 40, while here in the States, it climbed to #2 on Billboard’s Rock Chart–while continuing to pack dance floors across North America.

Then, At the end of the decade, VH-1 listed “Working for the Weekend” at #100 on their list of the 100 Greatest Songs of the ’80s!

So ironically, an empty beach inspired A Great Party Song of 1982!

1984’s“What About Me” is a Country Crossover that features an All-Star cast of singers and songwriters, and notable for the list of stars who DIDN’T make the lineup!

Get your scorecards ready, because here we go!

“What About Me” was written by Kenny Rogers, Richard Marx, and David Foster (known for his work with Chicago and scores of other artists, including his current wife, Katharine McPhee).

It was written as trio, and designed for Kenny, Lionel Ritchie, and Barbra Streisand, but then Lionel backed out, which led Barbra to back out as well.

So then it was offered to Olivia Newton-John and Jeffrey Osborne…but Olivia was working on a duet with Barry Gibb, and although she wanted to do it, the timing was wrong. Then Jeffrey had a scheduling conflict, so it was on to round 3.

The third time was the charm, as Kim Carnes and James Ingram stepped in to help Kenny complete”What About Me” as the lead single from his album” of the same name. Whew!

The song was a about a romantic triangle, with each singer trying to work out what they felt for whom, and it immediately became a hit, topping the Adult Contemporary Charts in both the US & Canada. (How could it lose with all that star power?)

Side Note: It was the first #1 song as a songwriter for Richard Marx.)

“What About Me” by Kenny Rogers, Kim Carnes, and James Ingram: an All-Star lineup with a Great Country Crossover…on from 1984!

The ’70s were quite the decade for John Denver: hit after hit, millions of albums and singles sold, TV specials and guest appearances, movies, extended tours, etc…etc…

The man was extremely busy for 10 straight years, so it was only natural that when the ’80s came around, he lightened his schedule and turned his attention to several special projects and humanitarian pursuits, many involving natural resource and environmental conservation.

John still toured a bit and released a few albums and singles here and there, but his main focus was elsewhere.

That said, his last big hit was released in 1982: the simple, yet beautiful “Shanghai Breezes.”

John was visiting Shanghai and was starting to feel homesick, when he realized that the sun, moon, stars, and even the breezes were the same no matter where he was at the time.

That simple thought gave birth to a song that went to #1 on the Adult Contemporary Charts in both the US and Canada.

It was John’s last #1 song…and also the last to appear in the Top 40 (at #31).

NOTE: In case you’ve ever wondered, the flute solos were performed by Jim Horn, a member of the legendary group of studio musicians called “The Wrecking Crew.” During his long career, Jim has played woodwinds for everyone from The Beatles and Beach Boys…to The Rolling Stones, The Carpenters., and Tom Petty–just to name a small handful.

“Shanghai Breezes” by John Denver: one last Great Song from a legendary performer.

If you’ve been following this blog for any given length of time, you’ve probably noticed that I often include Canadian chart statistics. There are 2 reasons for this:

#1: It’s no secret that many Canadian groups and artists have crossed over the border to influence American musical tastes…and vice versa.

#2: I grew up near the Canadian border, and it certainly influenced MY musical tastes! 🙂

On any given song, the chart numbers between countries could virtually be identical, or wildly different. And Then there are songs that don’t cross the border at all–and that can ALSO go both ways!

I bring this up because this week’s featured Great Song of the ’80s , is a rarity: a Great Canadian Song that took 6 YEARS to cross the border and become a Great Song here in the US!

In 1983, Arnold Lanni, keyboardist for the Canadian group Sherriff, fell in love with Valeri Brown and wrote her a song for Valentine’s Day. They married 2 years later, but before that happened, Sheriff recorded and released “When I’m With You.”

The song went to #8 on Canada’s Top 40, but stalled at #61 in the US.

Now You’d think that would be the end of it…and it almost WAS, especially after Sheriff turned in their badges and broke up in 1985.

But then, in November of 1988, KDWB in Minneapolis and WKTI in Milwaukee started playing the song…and by early 1989, other stations in the Midwest…and then the rest of the country… had started playing it as well, which led Capitol Records to re-issue the single.

This time, “When I’m With You” went to #1 on Billboard’s Hot 100 and Adult Contemporary Charts in the US …but failed to chart at all in Canada!

Many people thought Sheriff should reunite and go out on tour to back the song, but the ex-band members refused, and that was that.

So in the end, Sheriff became a one-hit wonder TWICE…with”When I’m with You:” a Great Song of 1983 up North…and 1989 here in the States.

For the stories behind more than 1,700 Great Songs of the ’70s and ’80s, visit my Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/MichaelCuuuk/

n the mid-80s, a lack of good material mixed with a serious drug problem put Eddie Money’s career on the skids. His record label, Columbia, was about ready to drop him, but, because he was cleaning himself up, they decided to give him one last chance–but only if he allowed them to choose his material. Eddie really had no choice but to agree.

One of the songs Columbia wanted him to record, was “Take Me Home Tonight.” Eddie didn’t think it had much hit potential, but he was intrigued by the part of the song that sampled “Be Me Baby,” the 1963 classic by the Ronettes–sung by Ronnie Spector (who, back in the day, was married to production genius–and future convicted murderer–Phil Spector).

Eddie thought it would be a good idea to have Ronnie record the part herself, but when he was told by Columbia that she wasn’t available…he asked his friend Martha Davis of the The Motels to sing it.

Martha declined and told Eddie he should call Ronnie himself and not take “No” for an answer.

So Eddie called Ronnie and caught her in the middle of washing dishes. Ronnie told him she’d retired because she was tired of all the drama stardom had brought her way. Basically, she was happy to be living a quiet life out of the spotlight.

But Eddie had a comeback ready: “But Ronnie, the whole song is a tribute to you!”

That did the trick!

The song was recorded and released as a single from Eddie’s “last chance” album, “Can’t Hold Back.” And people LOVED IT!

“Take Me Home Tonight” topped Billboard’s Mainstream Rock Chart, and reached #4 on the Hot 100! It later garnered a Grammy nomination for “Best male Rock Performance.” (Perhaps it should have been for “Best Duo,” but that’s just my personal opinion.)

Eddie Money was back…and so was Ronnie Spector, who then came out of retirement and resumed her singing career.

“Take me Home Tonight:” A double comeback for Eddie and Ronnie, and a Great Song of 1986!

Singer/Songwriter Paul Davis set out to write a song that would sound like something Hall & Oates might record, while at the same time, have sort of a nostalgic feel to it.

He called it: “55 Love Affair,” which, in itself, is a pretty good title, but the suits at Paul’s record company (Bang Records), had a question.

They asked Paul how old he was in 1955. The Answer…was 7.

At that point, they suggested he change the title to “65 Love Affair” since more people would believe a 17-year-old in love.

Excellent point, so Paul adjusted the title and lyrics accordingly.

And When the song was released as a single (from the album “Cool Night,” Paul did indeed sound a bit like Hall & Oates…and it was more believable, age-wise. SO believable, it spent FIVE MONTHS on Billboard’s Hot 100, peaking at #6. It also reached #5 on The Adult Contemporary Chart.

The moral of the story? Sometimes when you listen to the suits, you hit the charts with a BANG! Pun intended. “65 Love Affair” by Paul Davis: a Great Song of 1982!
